text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see. Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. text: Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. text: Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer.

text: Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we…

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
